title: When Melbourne's Metro Tunnel will open after decade-long wait
text:
M﻿elbourne's long-awaited Metro Tunnel is slated to open to the public in early December after years of construction, delays and cost blowouts.

Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan today announced the tunnel is scheduled to be complete and ready for passengers﻿ by the start of summer following eight years of construction.

The new tunnel will service trains every 20 minutes between Westall and West Footscray from 10am until 3pm Monday to Friday for an initial "Summer Start" period.

Melbourne Metro Tunnel will officially open in December. (Supplied)

Weeke﻿nd services trains will run every 20 minutes from 10am until 7pm, extending to East Pakenham every 40 minutes and Sunbury every hour.

﻿Metro Tunnel services will stop at five new underground stations: Arden, Parkville, State Library, Town Hall and Anzac.

A network-wide timetable for the new tunnel is scheduled to start on February 1 next year.﻿

Labelled "The Big Switch"﻿, this major timetable overhaul is set to add 1000 new weekly services to the network.

From this point, trains will run at least every 10 minutes from 6am until 10pm between Watergardens and Dandenong.

The new tunnel will service trains every 20 minutes between Westall and West Footscray. (Joe Armao)

﻿Metro Tunnel services will stop at five new underground stations: Arden, Parkville, State Library, Town Hall and Anzac. (Supplied)

The services will increase to every three to four minutes during rush hour.﻿

Frankston Line services are also expected to return to Melbourne's City Loop from February 1.

Allan said it was crucial to trial a smaller number of services first before integrating the big timetable switch.

﻿The premier could not confirm an exact date for the tunnel's opening and would only confirm it as "early December".

Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan did not divulge the exact date in December the Metro Tunnel would open. (Luis Enrique Ascui)

"Christmas is coming early for everyone on the Pakenham, Cranbourne and Sunbury lines, who'll have hundreds of new services every week from the start of December," Allan said.

﻿"What an incredible moment for our state – Victorians have patiently waited for this tunnel to get built underneath their feet and behind big sheds, and now they'll be able to use it."

The Melbourne Metro Tunnel was first announced in 2015.

Construction work began in 2017, including lengthy and complex work on Town Hall station which ﻿needed excavation as deep as a five storey building.

In September last year, t﻿he Allan government announced an $837 million cost blowout on the project.

title: New footage highlights growing problem for posties
text:
Posties around Australia are being injured by unsafe drivers at least five times a week.﻿

Australia Post has released footage of some of the terrifying accidents after it was revealed ﻿more than 280 posties have been injured in the past financial year.

Injuries have ranged from broken limbs and concussions to lacerations and serious trauma.﻿

Posties around Australia are being injured by cars at least five times a week.﻿ (Australia Post)

The injuries have required posties to undergo hospital treatment, take time off work and manage ongoing psychological trauma.

Australia Post general manager of safety Russell Munro said the figures were concerning.

"Every day our team members are out in communities delivering for Australians, but increasingly, they're also being put at risk by unsafe driver behaviour," Munro said.

Injuries have ranged from broken limbs and concussions to lacerations and serious trauma.﻿ (Australia Post)

"We are taking comprehensive measures, such as reducing our motorcycle fleet, expanding the deployment of electric delivery vehicles, and implementing upgraded telematics systems, including video and data monitoring across thousands of vehicles. ﻿

"Our data shows that the severity of injury to a postie when involved in a motor accident is reduced when operating an electric delivery vehicles.

"In some instances, our team have walked away from the accident with only minor injuries.﻿"

More than 280 posties have been injured in the past financial year. (Australia Post)

Posties have been involved in accidents when drivers have failed to give way, not left enough space to stop safety and cut corners.

Drivers have also put posties at risk by overtaking on the wrong side of the road, driving distracted while using a mobile phone and not looking on footpaths when using scooters and bikes.﻿

"Our priority is to deliver for all Australians whilst ensuring the safety of our team members, so they return home to their families safely each day," Munro said.

"However, road safety is a shared responsibility, and we urge all drivers to keep an eye out for our posties."

title: Half of Aussies think it's OK to commit this 'risky' WFH breach
text:
Exclusive: ﻿ Australian employees may be more lax about work from home (WFH) expectations in summer, according to a nine.com.au reader poll.

More than half of the 515* respondents think it's OK to clock off early to hit the beach during the warmer months.

One in four also ﻿said it's fine to take longer breaks to enjoy good weather while WFH in summer.

More than half of Aussie employees think it's OK to clock off early or take longer breaks when WFH in summer. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Nearly 40 per cent want ﻿companies to introduce more relaxed WFH rules in summer, like allowing staff to work half days on Fridays.

One third said ﻿employees should be allowed to work more days from home during summer.

The same amount said it's fine for Aussie employees to work from the beach or another outdoor location when WFH.

"As long as the work is being done why does it matter where it is done?" one respondent said.

Some respondents noted that these privileges should ﻿only be extended to workers who have proven they're reliable and get all their work done on time and to a high standard.

But Associate Professor of workplace and business law at the University of Technology, Sydney Giuseppe Carabetta said these habits raise practical and legal concerns.

"For employees working under traditional arrangements, it's risky to assume such freedom without prior approval," he told 9news.com.au.

"If the location compromises productivity or confidentiality, it could breach a company policy or even your employment contract."

He added that though ﻿flexible work arrangements are increasingly common, "employees generally can't unilaterally change their schedule".

So clocking off early or taking a longer break in summer isn't wise.

"For employees with set hours, clocking off early without approval could be considered time theft or a behavioural breach," Carabetta said.

﻿"For your typical salaried or award-regulated employees, longer breaks without approval could be seen as a breach of workplace expectations."﻿

But he wouldn't be surprised to see more Australian workplaces experimenting with or embracing "seasonal flexibility" in the future.

﻿That could look like summer hours of increased WFH allowances in the warmer months to boost morale and retention.

Such approaches would likely only be introduced in ﻿sectors where productivity isn't tied to physical presence.

But not everyone is on board.

A significant number of Aussies said that taking liberties with WFH policies in summer is tantamount to "stealing company time".

Of the 515 users surveyed, 35 per cent were against workers clocking off early in summer and almost 60 per cent said taking longer breaks was never OK.

﻿More than 45 per cent also said WFH rules shouldn't change with the weather.

And 54 per cent said it's never OK for Aussie employees to work from the beach or another outdoor location while WFH.

An additional 57 per cent said it would be inappropriate for workers to take ﻿work video calls or attend virtual meetings while working outdoors.

"Work means at work, not at the beach or some other location simply because of the day of the week or the season of the year," one said.﻿

A number of respondents said working from public locations like a beach or park could raise privacy concerns, depending on the work being done.

Carabetta agreed.

"Confidentiality is a cornerstone of professional conduct, and outdoor locations—whether it's a beach, café, or park - can pose risks," he said.

﻿"If you're dealing with confidential material, it's best to stick to secure, private locations."

READ MORE: Masked attackers set UK mosque on fire with people inside

More than 50 per cent of Aussies said employees should never work from the beach or another outdoor location while WFH. (Getty)

It's always better to ask for permission than forgiveness when it comes to WFH arrangements, even at relaxed workplaces.

﻿"Acting without approval could lead to disciplinary action or erode trust," Carabetta said.

"That said, many employers are open to flexibility - especially if approached transparently and respectfully and both parties are on the same page."

*The nine.com.au poll, which runs once a fortnight, canvases the views of the nine audience on 9Nation, which is an online community of our readers and viewers.

title: 'Flatter him': The plan PM should follow in meeting with Trump
text:
If those who rule us are not lying awake at night thinking about this, they should be: what do you do about a problem called Trump ?

With an unpredictable, abrasive, threatening and manipulative president of the United States, world leaders need masterclasses in Donald management or their countries may suffer.

So, as our PM packs the plane to head to his first real meeting with Mr Trump, he needs a plan.

Here's one strategy from a respected American commentator who has been analysing Trump for years.

First, flatter him.

Second, bow the head and treat him like the royalty he admires.

Third, recognise that traditional ties no longer exist.

And fourth, he's a salesman, always remember that.

Donald Trump: "Unpredictable, abrasive, threatening and manipulative." (AP)

James Kirchick, a commentator whose work appears in the New York Times and Wall Street Journal, says although Trump admires strength, he responds best to a strategy of admiration and subservience.

He says the fact Anthony Albanese is a left-wing prime minister will not help.

"Flatter him. Do something special for him. The Brits gave him this huge state dinner and the King was there. He loves royalty. He loves being treated like that.

"I wish we had a president who understood that regardless of which leader is in power our allies are our allies for reasons that go beyond that.

"Even though you have a left-wing prime minister it should not inhibit a positive relationship with the United States but unfortunately it does."

Anthony Albanese will need a game plan before he faces Donald Trump, an expert commentator says. (Getty)

Anthony Albanese clearly gives some thought to managing these leaders.

He turned up at 10 Downing Street with a four-pack of Albo Ale as a gift.

Let's hope Kevin Rudd and the diplomatic team don't let that happen at the White House.

Trump doesn't drink.

He lost his brother to alcohol addiction and won't go near it.

Regardless of the gift, it's a crucial meeting with so much uncertainty about relations between the two countries: tariffs, the submarine deal, the defence alliance, and Chinese expansion all need to be discussed.

They are due to meet on October 20.

It has taken too long to organise, which shows where Australia sits on the US agenda.

But the game has changed in many ways for a nation we still see as our defender.

Kirchick spoke on my podcast, Neil Mitchell Asks Why.

"Democratic allies need to understand that simply being a liberal democracy, which used to mean you were an ally because you had the same values, doesn't mean anything anymore.

"The Trump administration doesn't care about those airy fairy romantic things like democracy and liberal values and historical ties.

"The don't care about that. They care about, 'Let's make a deal. What's good for us?'"

James Kirchick is a journalist, author and commentator. (James Kirchick)

Before he's branded as a left-wing part of the "fake news" conspiracy, it must be said Kirchick is seen in the US as a conservative commentator, although he admits voting Democrat recently.

He loathes Nazis and what they stand for but says they have the right to march in the streets.

He is critical of immigration levels.

And he says the people must be armed in case they need to protect themselves from a "tyrannical and authoritarian" government.

But back to Trump management.

Kirchick says:

He is hugely inconsistent. After there was political violence, he said the country must come together, then soon after called for the destruction of the left.

He primarily believes in himself.

He has a deep need for approval.

He is contradictory – he admires strength but seeks subservience.

He wants to be remembered for "making America strong" and respected.

And China, which is expanding in the Pacific, lustfully eyeing Taiwan and both duchessing and spying on Australia.

Will the US step in if needed?

KIRCHICK: "Well, he responds to strength in the way that, if you saw the Israeli attack on the Iranian nuclear sites, which was successful in its initial stage, and then he decided, all right, I want to be a part of this. I want to be able to claim credit for it.

"So if you're ever in some kind of spat with the Chinese in the Pacific, you better damn make sure you're doing well.

"If you're not doing well, then he's not going to come in and save you. I mean, he's just not.

MITCHELL: Really? That's frightening to Australia. It is frightening.

KIRCHICK: Look, I was maybe being a little facetious. I would hope in a situation like that, that Donald Trump has people around him, who would be telling him, 'Mr President, it's very important for the United States that we support our allies in this situation. It's good for us. It'll make us look strong. It'll make us respected. And it'll send a message to the Chinese. Don't f--- with us.'"

So are the tantrums and absurdly extreme statements tactical or genuine? What do we believe?

"He's a salesman and he always has been. If you look at where his money came from, it's from selling things.

"Like many salesmen, he makes big, grand promises. That's just part of his nature, that's part of his personality.

"And I do think to some extent in his negotiating strategy and he's very open about this, he puts it on the table and his opening offer will be something outrageous, you know, just something totally outrageous."

Finally, although it makes the left shudder, does he really want the Nobel Peace Prize?

"I think he absolutely wants it. He's been saying for a long time that he deserves the Nobel Peace Prize.

"And by the way, I would say he deserves it a lot more than Barack Obama did.

"Barack Obama got it eight months into his presidency.

"He didn't do anything."

title: Aussies have been repaid $1.76 billion in lost wages - who are the worst offenders?
text:
Wage theft has more than doubled in Australia in the past five years, according to a new analysis of data from the Fair Work Ombudsman.

Software company Reckon published the report , which also detailed the worst sectors for wage theft.

Overall, in the financial years from 2019-2020 to 2023-2024, more than 16,700 investigations into wage theft were completed, with 9401 businesses (56 per cent) found to be non-compliant.

Australians have been repaid $1.76 billion in lost wages in recent years. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

More than $1.76 billion was repaid to workers in that time, with penalties increasing sharply.﻿

During the past five financial years, the public administration and safety sector recorded the highest rate of wage non-compliance in Australia, with 932.3 non-compliant businesses per 100,000.

This led to more than $270,000 being repaid to workers within the sector.

The accommodation and food services industry ranked second, but surpassed the public administration and safety sector in both number of requests for assistance, or RFAs (11,369 to 1390) and number of non-compliant businesses (2553 to 163).

"Our research reveals that wage theft continues to be a significant issue across Australia, with over 16,700 investigations completed and more than 9400 businesses found non-compliant over the past five financial years," Reckon chief executive Sam Allert said.

"The scope of this issue is highlighted by the $1.76 billion that was repaid to workers, emphasising the far-reaching consequences for businesses that fail to comply."

READ MORE: Masked attackers set UK mosque on fire with people inside

Mining workers were one of the workforces most affected. (Getty)

The other industries that landed in the top 10 worst wage theft offenders - judged by how many businesses per 100,000 Reckon found to be non-compliant - included administrative and support services (281.8); other services (221.2); retail trade (199.6); electricity, gas, water, and waste services (199.3); transport, postal, and warehousing (198.2); arts and recreation services (195.5); manufacturing (179.8); and mining (177.8).

Mining was at the top spot in terms of the average amount of money recovered per non-compliant business, at more than $4.5 million.

That was followed by the utilities service sector at more than $2.5 million.﻿

The report also found wage theft levels differed state to state, with the Northern Territory the worst offender in relative terms, followed by Tasmania, Queensland, South Australia, the ACT, Victoria, New South Wales, and Western Australia.

The data also appeared to show most wage theft inquiries were initiated by employees rather than self-reported by employers - though an RFA is not a per se indicator of any discrepancy in remuneration.﻿

"Businesses can protect themselves by regularly reviewing payroll systems, staying informed about industry-specific regulations, and promptly addressing any discrepancies," Allert said.

"By implementing robust compliance frameworks, investing in ongoing training, and utilising technology, businesses can not only avoid the costly consequences of non-compliance but also build a strong level of trust with their employees, ensuring a fairer and more sustainable work environment."

title: Dozens of fires burn across Queensland as severe weather season looms
text:
Just a day after crews contained an out-of-control bushfire — and with 60 fires currently burning across the state — Queenslanders are being urged to prepare for an impending severe weather season.

Parts of the state are still reeling from last season's flooding, storms and rainfall, with the majority of council areas disaster-declared already.

Loading...

A blaze on Moreton Island — believed to have been sparked on Saturday by a campfire while an active fire ban was in place — burnt 2,300 kilometres before it was brought under control.

Elsewhere, two fires are continuing to burn in the Bundaberg region with both at watch and act levels.

A fire ban across Central Queensland has been extended until October 10, while a fire ban remains in place for the state's south-east.

Large swathes of Queensland are also experiencing above-average temperatures, with about 60 fires burning on Tuesday.

In some places, recovery is sitll underway from events like ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred. (ABC News: Syan Vallance)

Queensland Fire Department Commissioner Steve Smith said the fire season was looking "average", but high fuel loads from multiple recent wet seasons was a risk.

"As we've seen over the last week, we'll have these bursts of severe activity," he said.

Commissioner Smith said the frequency and intensity of bushfires had increased in recent years, and it was "frustrating" to have to respond to fires like the one on Moreton Island, which was believed to have been entirely avoidable.

Communities still reeling

Speaking on Tuesday morning, Emergency Services Minister Ann Leahy said many communities were still feeling the impacts of extreme weather.

Betting on the weather emerges as a solution as insurance costs skyrocket Photo shows Two woman stand in a burnt building with masks on Amid more extreme weather events, parametric insurance — described as a bet on the weather —is on the rise. It is now being touted as a possible solution for Australians, who have some of the highest insurance losses in the world.

She said 73 of 77 local council areas were already disaster-declared, following flooding and storms from last season.

"We still have places that are recovering from the events of this year," she said.

State Disaster Coordinator Christopher Stream said Queensland experienced some "record-breaking" events last disaster season, and was the most impacted by disasters in the country.

"We know that Queensland is experiencing more disasters, more intense disasters," he said.

Not just fire

Fire bans are in place across a large swathe of Queensland. (ABC News: Molly Slattery)

The Bureau of Meteorology's (BOM) long-range forecasts are predicting above-average rainfall for the state's south-east and far north between now and January.

Severe storms are also expected, while an average of three to four tropical cyclones cross Australia's coast each season.

Flooding from Tropical Cyclone Jasper caused extensive damage. (Supplied: Transport and Main Roads Queensland)

Brisbane Lord Mayor Adiran Schrinner said residents needed to be ready for "quite violent storms".

"Every summer ... we want to make sure that people are aware that it can be any kind of natural disaster that comes our way," he said.

" We started this year with a cyclone that no-one expected, we've just had, over the weekend, bushfires raging. "

Parts of Brisbane are experiencing "unseasonable" temperatures. (ABC News: Curtis Rodda)

'Unseasonable' warmth in Brisbane and the south-east

Above-average temperatures being experienced around Brisbane and parts of the state's south-east are forecast to remain throughout the coming week, according to the Bureau of Meteorology.

Spring heatwave increases fire risk as scores of blazes burn in Queensland Photo shows A crowded beach in front of a city skyline. Temperatures could soar to almost 10 degrees above average this week, increasing the risk of bushfires that are already burning across the state.

BOM senior meteorologist Harry Clark said temperatures of between 32 and 35 degrees Celsius being experienced throughout the region were roughly five degrees above average.

On Saturday, temperatures are expected to hit a "quite unseasonable" top of high 30s.

Mr Clarke said the "phenomenal October heat", which was being driven by a low-pressure trough funnelling warm winds over the region, would peak over the weekend.

There is also a chance of rainfall over the weekend, but Mr Clarke said that prediction was "fairly hit and miss".

A total fire ban remains in place for south-east Queensland until 11:59pm on Tuesday, while fire bans in the state's central region — including the South Burnett, Bundaberg, Gladstone and Gympie areas — have been extended until October 10.

High fire danger along the south-east coast is expected to drop back to moderate from Wednesday to Friday, although smoke haze is expected to linger throughout the coming days, Mr Clarke said.

title: NT parents referred to income management if kids fail to attend class
text:
Parents in the Northern Territory who frequently fail to send their children to school without a valid reason will be referred to the Commonwealth for income management, under a new NT government policy.

Previously, the NT Department of Education and Training had the power to issue $370 fines and compliance notices to those parents, but only child protection officers could make referrals.

The policy, which comes into effect today, adds to the enforcement powers granted to officers last year as part of the NT government's broader strategy to improve dwindling school attendance rates.

Jo Hersey is the NT's education minister. (ABC News: Xavier Martin)

'Get your kids to school'

On Monday, NT Education and Training Minister Jo Hersey said parents of "chronically disengaged children" would be considered for an income management arrangement on a "case-by-case" basis.

"We are making sure that we are not only getting back to basics, boosting literacy and numeracy in schools, but we want kids to actually attend school," she said.

" If you don't want to be income managed, and if you don't want a fine, get your kids to school. "

Ms Hersey could not say how much of a parent's income would be quarantined under the scheme, or how it would be managed, calling those details "operational issues"

She claimed the Country Liberal Party (CLP) had "returned 328 students to classrooms" since it came to power in August 2024.

Indigenous advocates say the plan will disproportionately impact remote communities. (Supplied: Facebook/NT Department of Education)

People on income management in the Northern Territory have some of their Centrelink payment quarantined into a separate account which can only be spent on essentials.

The new policy effectively removes a step from the NT government's previous process to recommend income management for parents of children who fail to attend school.

Last year, Ms Hersey said the NT Department of Education could refer parents who failed to pay $370 truancy fines to the federal government for income management, based on NT provisions already in place.

Concern policy may 'stigmatise families'

Justine Davis says the move could create more stigma and access barriers. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Independent MLA Justine Davis said income management was not effective at addressing social issues and suggested the CLP was taking the "lazy" approach by punishing families.

"Multiple evaluations have shown it doesn't improve child outcomes, doesn't increase school attendance, and doesn't reduce disadvantage," she said.

" What it does do is stigmatise families, create barriers to accessing services, and add administrative burden without addressing the root causes of non-attendance. "

In a statement, a spokesperson for human rights group Justice Not Jails said parents should be supported rather than punished when their children weren't going to school.

The group said there were "many reasons why children may not feel they want to be at school" and cited a 2024 NT Children's Commissioner report which found up to 80 per cent of children in the Northern Territory had experienced or observed racism at school.

Justice not Jails also characterised the policy as "a hark back to the paternalism of The Intervention", "whose humiliating policies undermined the autonomy and self-determining capacities of families and communities".

Marion Scrymgour says the federal government will decide if parents are involuntarily put on income management. (ABC News: Chris Murrkarany Fitzpatrick)

Northern Territory federal MP Marion Scrymgour questioned whether a "punitive" use of income management would improve outcomes and suggested the new referral pathway could instead be used as an opportunity to provide families with other government supports.

"This doesn't compel people to change their behaviour. We need to ask, how do we get better outcomes here?"," she said.

"Let's use this as an opportunity to work with those families, but also with the NT government, so that we can turn around these really bad outcomes that we have in our school system."

Ms Scrymgour said the Commonwealth had the final say on whether an individual was involuntarily placed on income management.

title: Future of Australia's last paper mill hangs in balance ahead of key energy talks
text:
Australia's last paper mill and supplier of newsprint remains locked in negotiations for power security, with owner David Marriner saying Tasmanian government-owned energy retailer Aurora has knocked back his offer for compromise.

As one of Tasmania's major industrials, the Boyer pulp and paper mill in New Norfolk is also one the state's largest power users.

Aurora Energy is seeking a $7 million bank guarantee to cover energy costs for the mill as it looks to electrify and move away from its coal-powered boilers.

The state-owned power business says credit security requirements are "entirely consistent with the treatment of all other large electricity users in Tasmania".

Aurora said it had been engaged in discussions since June this year, which had been "constructive and flexible with Boyer management on the timing and parameters of credit security".

"When it comes to large customer electricity bills, it is critical that Aurora Energy operates commercially and manages its financial risk, given 90 per cent of its dividend is returned to the Tasmanian people."

David Marriner says Aurora's request for a $7 million guarantee is "obscene". (ABC News: Sophie Jaggers)

Melbourne businessman David Marriner, who purchased the facility in February, said the proposal was unreasonable.

"It's just an insane, an obscene request," Mr Marriner said.

The Boyer Mill, which is currently Tasmania's fourth-largest carbon emitter, is working to convert its coal boilers to electric after years of energy concerns.

Loading...

Key negotiations to take place today

A meeting about the power agreement is scheduled for Tuesday afternoon, with representatives from the mill, Aurora and the Tasmanian government set to take part.

Ahead of the meeting, Mr Marriner said his company's reply proposal of a $2.5 million guarantee and more frequent payments had not been accepted by Aurora.

"I certainly hope commonsense prevails [at the meeting] and I'm hoping that there is goodwill at the table at the present," Mr Marriner said.

Energy Minister Nick Duigan urged the two parties to negotiate in good faith. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Mr Marriner, who is also scheduled to meet with the facility's 300 staff today, said his company was "absolutely committed" to securing the best outcome.

"I know what it's like to see a factory close down. Once that happens, it's never likely to reopen," he said.

"We're there to make sure we can secure the ongoing future of the mill, secure the future of their jobs.

"These are people who have an enormous responsibility to carry on an 80-year legacy.

"I will be in the trenches with them to see that their job is continued, and certainly do the best that we can possibly do."

The paper mill is Tasmania's fourth-largest carbon emitter. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Tasmania's energy minister, Nick Duigan, urged both parties to continue negotiating in good faith.

"Aurora must always act in the best interests of Tasmanians taxpayers," he said.

"We encourage the new owner of Boyer to invest in the business."

Power will be cut if negotiations fail, owner says

The mill is Australia's last paper mill and producer of newsprint, which is used for newspapers, and the uncertainty of its operations comes at a time that print media is also in decline.

Paper mill owner told no spare energy for electric conversion Photo shows Building with thick white steam coming out Australia's only paper mill uses coal-fired boilers, which its new owner wants to convert to electric. But he says he has been told there is not enough local power in the Tasmanian grid to support this.

Its boiler, installed in 1991, consumes about 88,000 tonnes of coal from New South Wales each year.

Mr Marriner wants to change that by going electric — as the previous owners, Norwegian company Norske Skog, had also explored.

But supplier Hydro Tasmania has consistently pushed back on this — arguing there is not enough power in Tasmania's grid to supply the facility.

The mill would instead need to import electricity from Victoria.

Mr Marriner said he was told power to the mill would be cut if negotiations fail at today's meeting.

The union says generations of families have worked at the mill. (ABC News: Luke Bowden )

The Australian Manufacturers Union's state secretary, Jacob Batt, said workers were "incredibly concerned" about the direction of negotiations.

"It really puts a lot of pressure on the company and on the jobs," Mr Batt said.

"Some of the workers at the mill, generations of their family, have been working at the Boyer Mill since it started.

"There's a long history of families in the Derwent Valley that have worked at the mill. Some of the workers there themselves have been working there for over 40 years.

Mr Batt said along with the mill's 300 employees, there were 1,000 indirect jobs connected to the mill, including timber workers.

title: 'It's a storyline from Neighbours': Op shops serve up a slice of TV history
text:
When Rebecca Brewin dropped into her local op shop in Melbourne's east a few days ago, she had no idea she was just a footstep away from some pieces of Australian television history.

"I go in there a lot and I've developed a bit of a friendship with Michelle, the manager," Ms Brewin said.

"She said 'oh come out the back, I've just had the weirdest donation.'"

Fake drivers licences and Medicare cards were found inside Dr Karl Kennedy's medical bag donated to a Forest Hill op shop. (Instagram: becbrewinthrift)

Out the back of the This N That Community Op Shop in Forest Hill, amongst piles of ornaments, table lamps and other homewares were Erinsborough High school bags, fake licences, fake Medicare cards, keys on a Lassiters Spa key ring and a familiar looking bag.

Loading Instagram content

"She showed me this briefcase which turned out to be Dr Karl's medical bag."

Three weeks ago, Michelle (who asked that her surname not be used) was approached by someone who had three van loads of donations.

"They said 'oh it's from the set of Neighbours,'" Michelle said.

"I was like 'oh, that's pretty cool.'"

Ms Brewin asked Michelle if she could post a video of the donations on her social media channels.

"They went to so much detail," Ms Brewin said.

"I had no idea that they would have created fake drivers licences, fake IDs, fake bank cards for all these characters."

Michelle confesses to being more of a Home and Away fan and said she did not expect what happened after Ms Brewin posted her video.

"Over the weekend, we opened at 10am and we had a line of people out the front, we were just inundated."

She said she had phone calls from the UK, New Zealand and around Australia.

" We're just a little op shop that didn't expect this to blow up and go this viral. "

From the small screen to a suburban second-hand store

Just like when any family moves, all the possessions no longer needed to create the homes of the fictitious residents of Ramsay Street have been donated to op shops around Melbourne.

After four decades, filming of the Australia television show has come to an end — for a second time.

Only a footstep away Photo shows A man and a woman embrace, while looking at the camera. After nearly 9,000 episodes, 63 weddings, 20 births and 68 deaths, Neighbours is coming to an end.

Streaming service Amazon announced earlier this year that it was ceasing production of the internationally-renowned soapie after throwing the axed show a lifeline in 2022.

All the sets have been dismantled and decades of props, furniture and clothing have been given away, including to a number of unsuspecting thrift stores.

Michelle said she had to knock back the furniture because her op shop was too small to hold it.

But she did accept pallets of mostly homewares and bags.

Lamps that once sat on a table of a restaurant in Neighbours are now up for sale at the op shop. (ABC News: Daryl Torpy)

Some from the famous Kennedy household or the fictitious Lassiters Hotel have already been sold.

"People are like 'this was in the Kennedys' house!' and I'm like 'oh, I don't know,'" she said.

" I would put things for $10 because I'd be like 'oh who wants this?' "

Andrew James does.

Mr James is in Melbourne from the UK, and arrived at the shop on Monday after visiting Pin Oak Court in the neighbouring suburb of Vermont South — the street where the show was filmed.

He said he had been a fan all his life and, after seeing the social media post, hoped to pick up a memento.

"I'd treasure it," he said.

"My mother will tell you that when I was a baby, the Neighbours theme tune used to stop me crying so it's been a big part of my life."

Neighbours fan Andrew James went to the Forest Hill store to hunt memorabilia. (ABC News)

Mr James said he moved to Australia after becoming intrigued by the characters' lifestyle on the show.

"You'd see the characters in the sunshine, going out in the pool, things like that.

"I'm not looking to buy lots of things, just a small keepsake."

Sienna Macalister inspects a picnic basket used as a prop on Neighbours. (ABC News: Daryl Torpy)

Sienna Macalister was hoping to snap up a backpack, school dress or another prop from Erinsborough High.

The attire was more familiar to them than their own school uniform after they worked dozens of times as an extra in school scenes when they were a child.

"I was there when the school burnt down, when there was a school camp," they recalled.

More recognisable Neighbours props, like this Erinsborough High backpack, will be sold at a special evening organised by the Forest Hill op shop. (ABC News: Daryl Torpy)

"I was there very, very frequently to the point where my school turned around and said 'you can't do it anymore' because I was missing too much schooling.

"We changed schools so I could keep going."

Ms Macalister described their time on set as magical and said it had inspired them to pursue a career as an actor and writer.

They said they was relieved when Amazon saved Neighbours only to be disappointed by its second axing.

"I just think it's so important and such a crucial training ground for Australia, and also it's just such a fantastic show. It should continue."

Museum or op shop: Fans disagree on fate of props

"I recognised it! I can't remember which house it is from now, but …"

Sarah Jones scored an ornament from the long-running soap.

Sarah Jones snapped up an ornament that she recognised from Neighbours. (ABC News: Daryl Torpy)

She went to the Forest Hill op shop to try to "rescue" some items to send to Neighbours fans in the UK.

"It's a bit upsetting really that they would just dump some of this stuff that people would really treasure," Ms Jones said.

"A lot of people have said it should go into a museum or something.

"Things like this, it's just a little cheap ornament, but some of the things there like the scripts and characters' iconic costuming, it's just kind of a bit disrespectful to the show really."

Fellow Neighbours fan Michael Drake disagrees.

"Karl's briefcase should be in a museum, I reckon, or on display saying 'not for sale,'" he said.

"[But] in a way, I don't think it is disrespectful. It's sort of giving fans of Neighbours a chance to own a piece of the show."

Michael Drake says Neighbours was life-changing for him. (ABC News: Daryl Torpy)

Mr Drake drove across Melbourne to see what he could find.

He said the show played an important role in his life.

"It's saved me through so many things growing up," he said

"I struggled with my identity in a way and when they introduced the first gay character, Chris, years ago, I still remember it.

" That just helped me accept my myself and let me enjoy life a bit more. "

He said he was glad the memorabilia had been donated to a small community store instead of the larger op shop.

Matthew Myers found a vase that had been used in Neighbours. (ABC News: Daryl Torpy)

Matthew Myers runs a website featuring celebrity interviews and reviews.

He thinks the props ending up in op shops is fitting.

"It's kind of like a story that would be on Neighbours!" Mr Myers exclaimed.

"It would have made a great story for Dr Karl to come in here and find his attache case."

Not good friends — lawyers make demands after donation

The volunteer-based op shop is linked to the Lutheran church, and manager, Michelle, said the money goes to helping people in the community with things like hospice care and children's camps.

A Medicare card prop from Neighbours was found inside a wallet amongst the donations. (Instagram: becbrewinthrift)

"We're very community based, we'll help people like single mums and people leaving domestic violence and things," she said.

Costumes from Neighbours were donated to a Fitzroy op shop. (ABC News: Shannon Schubert)

More iconic props, including Karl Kennedy's briefcase, the school bags and umbrellas with the Neighbours logo remained in storage to be sold off at a special, invitation-only event.

The details, including the date and whether it would take the form of an auction or another type of sale, were yet to be confirmed.

But what Michelle could say was that it would not include donated scripts of episodes yet to be aired.

Late on Monday morning, she got a phone call from lawyers demanding she destroy the scripts, which she said she would do.

Meanwhile, more props have been spotted at other op shops in and around Melbourne, including clothing at the Sacred Heart Mission store in Fitzroy.

title: Midlife loneliness on the rise in Canberra as financial pressures bite
text:
Loneliness is rising fastest among Canberrans in their 30s and 40s, with new research showing this cohort is now more likely than younger people to report feeling lonely.



The University of Canberra's latest Living Well in the ACT Region report, released this week by the Health Research Institute, found that one in five respondents — or 18.8 per cent — aged 30 to 49 reported feeling lonely "often" or "always".

The result marks a shift from last year, when 18 to 29 year olds reported the highest rates of loneliness in the ACT.



Drawn from a survey of more than 3,100 ACT residents conducted in late 2024, the findings also point to a broader decline in wellbeing across the population.

About 31.2 per cent of all respondents reported low levels of wellbeing — the highest since the survey began in 2019 — echoing trends seen in national wellbeing and happiness data.

University of Canberra Associate Professor Jacki Schirmer says the rise in the cost of living led to the shift. (ABC News: Mark Moore)

Lead researcher Associate Professor Jacki Schirmer said financial pressure and time scarcity were compounding social disconnection.

"Particularly people aged 30 to 49 — you've got kids at home, they might have a big mortgage," Associate Professor Schirmer said.

" We're seeing a lot of stress in that group that wasn't there a few years ago. "

Associate Professor Schirmer said the cost-of-living crisis was impacting people's social expenditure.

"A bit over two in five Canberrans said they've cancelled one or more social events in the last year because they were struggling financially. So they couldn't afford the coffee at the cafe, the restaurant dinner or to bring something to the BBQ," she said.

"These things are really intersecting. We already had some challenges with social connection, and it's become bigger as people struggle financially and experience those cost-of-living pressures."

Community connection rebounds — for some

Despite worsening loneliness for midlife adults, the report found that community participation had improved overall.

The share of ACT residents regularly taking part in community activities rose to 66.4 per cent by the end of 2024 from 55 per cent in early 2023.

In Canberra, community-led organisations were helping drive that shift.



Former Brumbies and Wallabies player Ben Alexander co-founded Running for Resilience nearly six years ago with Matthew Breen, after being approached by the young Brumbies fan to host a social run. Mr Breen had recently lost his father to suicide and his mother had just received a cancer diagnosis.

"We thought this was just a one-off run to try and get people active," Alexander said.

" But over the years, we've realised social connection is probably almost more important for mental health than exercise, which was a huge shock to me and made me realise I was incredibly lonely in the years after retiring. "

Ben Alexander says he has realised the importance of social connection in recent years. (Hannah Johnston)

What began as a small run followed by a free beer at The Dock in Kingston, has since developed into a registered charity that now hosts up to 16 weekly events across Canberra, including running, walking, yoga, and pickleball sessions.

"People come to get fit, but they stay for the connection," Alexander said.

"We're really trying to make it so easy for anyone to rock up, do some exercise, and have a chat with someone and make a friend."

Choir offers connection through music

In north Canberra, another group finding strength in shared connection is the LGBTQIA+ community choir QWire.

Convenor Erin Pynor said membership had grown from fewer than 100 to about 150 singers in the two years since she joined, with many new members aged 30 to 49.

"We're seeing people use [QWire] as a way to meet others — some are into music, some just love the queerness, the community, the connection they're getting here," they said.

Erin Pynor has found a sense of community by singing with Canberra Qwire.

The choir rehearses weekly in Lyneham and performs regularly at community events and concerts.

"I fit firmly into the [30–49] cohort myself and joined [QWire] to find community when I moved back to Canberra after a period away," Erin Pynor said.

"It really was just like a life-transforming kind of thing.

" I now have someone who sells eggs and I get them every week, someone else nearby who I carpool with, and another who has small children — we have play dates and things like that. "

Over-65s 'doing pretty well'

The survey shows that while loneliness remains a concern for many Canberrans, older adults, particularly those aged 65 and higher, are reporting notably high levels of wellbeing.

"They're doing pretty well," Associate Professor Schirmer said.

"Even some of the groups that typically have very high wellbeing saw a little bit of a loss, but that 65-and-over demographic — if you're in a good relationship and own your home — then you've got a much higher likelihood of having good levels of wellbeing than a lot of other groups."

title: UEFA makes 'regrettable' decision to allow Italian Serie A match in Perth
text:
Seven-time European champions AC Milan are heading to Perth to play an Italian league game in a historic but controversial first.

The Union of European Football Associations (UEFA) has "reluctantly" agreed to allow a regular Serie A match between Milan and Como to be staged in the West Australian capital in February.

European football's governing body also said on Monday it would permit Barcelona and Villarreal to play their December Spanish league clash in Miami.

However, UEFA said it disapproved of clubs taking matches overseas and would work to prevent this setting a precedent.

Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA), the international governing body, must also assent to the games, but that is expected to be a formality.

Spain's La Liga has been pursuing a transatlantic vision for almost a decade, emulating the strategy employed by the NFL and NBA to establish themselves in other markets.

Spain and Italy have already held Super Cup matches overseas.

The Premier League considered the concept 17 years ago but shelved it due to supporter opposition.

Germany's Bundesliga has said it has no plans to take games abroad.

Milan decided to move its game after learning the San Siro stadium would be unavailable while the city and venue prepared to host the Winter Olympics opening ceremony on February 6.

Perth has been chosen, in part, as the club has been cultivating links with Australia for many years, not least due to the huge Italian diaspora present.

Milan played Roma in Perth in 2024 and the Glory in July this year.

The Roma match was at Perth Stadium, drawing 56,522 fans, and it is anticipated that the Rossoneri will play Como at the same venue.

Besides its continental success, the club has won 19 domestic titles, most recently in 2022.

The current squad includes former Real Madrid star Luka Modric, of Croatia, Christian Pulisic from the US, and Portugal's Rafael Leao.

Como, coached by ex-Arsenal, Chelsea and Barcelona star Cesc Fabregas, has Spain's Alvaro Morata and Brazil's Diego Carlos in its ranks.

'It is regrettable'

For decades, many notable foreign clubs have played friendlies in Australia, but this will be the first major competitive club game involving overseas teams.

UEFA's hand appears to have been forced by a court case successfully brought by an American promoter, who wanted to stage matches in the US.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

FIFA withdrew from a legal action brought by Relevent in a Manhattan court 18 months ago and subsequently formed a working group, including UEFA lawyers, that is yet to report.

Ironically, Relevent has since become a key commercial partner of UEFA.

"League matches should be played on home soil; anything else would disenfranchise loyal match-going fans and potentially introduce distortive (sic) elements in competitions," UEFA president Aleksander Ceferin said in a statement.

"While it is regrettable to have to let these two games go ahead, this decision is exceptional and shall not be seen as setting a precedent.

"Our commitment is clear: to protect the integrity of national leagues and ensure that football remains anchored in its home environment."

Serie A president Ezio Simonelli took a different view.

"For us, a contingency due to the unavailability of San Siro stadium has turned into an opportunity to satisfy the many fans of Italian football, who will have the chance to watch the match live in Perth," he said.

title: Farmer says northern food bowl a 'pipe dream' amid changing climate
text:
Abundant water, wide stretches of undeveloped land, and proximity to Asia once positioned northern Australia as the nation's next big food bowl.

But that dream has largely wilted under the weight of economic pressures, logistical challenges, and a changing climate.

Parker Poynt Packhouse founder Quentin Parker has lived in the Ord Valley for nearly 40 years — home to the highest average temperature of any mango-growing region in the north, and about 3,000 kilometres from Perth.

Now retired, he still maintains about 460 mango trees on his property, though they yield little fruit.

Quentin Parker says the productivity of his trees has dropped significantly. (ABC Kimberley: Jess Baker)

He said business was booming for a time, but things changed after 2011.

"[2011] was the biggest year. I did 123,500 trays that year," he said.

"And then, the following year, I think it was 70,000-odd.

"I thought my throat had been cut."

Since then, the number of trays processed through his business has fallen by about 10,000 each year.

In 2024, he processed just 2,500 trays.

This year, he expects to hand-pack only 500.

Mr Parker suspects changing climate patterns may be partly to blame, but admits it is hard to say for sure.

"I don't know, we're doing something wrong with the world," he said.

The mango trees on Quentin Parker's property yield little fruit nowadays. (ABC Kimberley: Jess Baker)

Mr Parker described the idea of northern Australia becoming a food bowl as a "pipe dream".

"Unless we can attract a whole new generation of pioneers here, probably we're not going to see it," he said.

Big vision, harsh reality

Central to the food bowl vision were Lake Argyle and Lake Kununurra in Western Australia's East Kimberley region.

The lakes were formed by damming the Ord River in the 1960s and 70s and diverting it into the Ord River Irrigation Scheme, enabling large-scale farming near Kununurra.

Early plans envisioned the scheme would turn the remote north into a major food-producing region, growing crops such as cotton, sugarcane, and rice.

Lake Argyle was formed in 1973 to supply water to the Ord River Irrigation Area. (ABC Rural: Matt Brann)

But not everyone agreed with that vision, even within government.

In 2014, then-agriculture minister Barnaby Joyce dismissed the idea that Australia could feed Asia's growing population.

"We only produce about one per cent of the agricultural product of the world and to start saying that this country … is going to be a predominant player on the global stage is not correct," he told ABC News Breakfast at the time.

"We couldn't even feed half of Indonesia … stop talking about 'we're going to feed the whole of Asia.'"

Former agriculture minister Barnaby Joyce talked down claims Australia could 'feed the whole of Asia'. (AAP: Lukas Coch)

Climate risk rising

The federal government's newly released National Climate Risk Assessment predicts northern Australia will face increasing hazards as global temperatures rise.

Central Queensland University adjunct professor of environmental geography Steve Turton said the region was nearing its "thermal limits" for cropping and cattle, effectively ending the food bowl dream.

"[If] we don't take the right course, then I do believe that it's dead and buried," he said.

"We are near the top of thermal limits for a couple of important tree crops like mangoes and avocados.

"[They're] not getting enough cool nights in the winter when they need to flower or have fruit set."

A new role for the north

Cooperative Research Centre for Developing Northern Australia chief scientist Allan Dale said the food bowl dream was outdated.

"About 10 years ago, the idea of the north being the biggest, best food bowl for the wider south-east Asian region and beyond was really modified," he said.

"There was a shift in language from the north being the food bowl to the north being a very targeted, very powerful agricultural development opportunity."

The Ord Valley is known for diverse agriculture, particularly cotton, grains, and horticultural crops. (ABC Kimberley: Alys Marshall)

Dr Dale said the region had a crucial role to play, particularly as southern Australia faced increased drought risk.

"We know we're going to have greater drought risk in the south, and if northern Australia gets its agricultural development right, then it actually becomes extremely important for Australia's overall climate resilience," he said.

Dr Dale emphasised the need for strong collaboration across governments, industries, communities, and traditional owners to realise the region's potential.

title: LeBron James teases 'Second Decision', prompting retirement speculation
text:
LeBron James has once again got the eyes of the NBA world on him, and he did it with a 10-second clip on social media.

Heading into his 23rd NBA season, James posted to his accounts a mysterious video of himself walking to a chair across from an unknown interviewer in the middle of a basketball court.

The video is accompanied by the phrase "The decision of all decisions", with the full reveal apparently set for 1am Wednesday AEDT.

Naturally, speculation immediately began that it was a retirement announcement.

James will turn 41 on December 30, two months into the 2025/26 season, when he will play his second season alongside son Bronny with the Los Angeles Lakers.

When he turns out for his first game, presumably in the Lakers' season opener against Golden State on October 22, he will break the record for the most seasons played in the NBA.

If he plays 50 games he will pass former Chicago and Boston centre Robert Parrish for the most games played in the league.

So a retirement announcement would not be unreasonable and would afford him a season-long farewell tour.

The title card of "The Second Decision" is an allusion to his infamous 2010 special The Decision, when he stunned the league with a free-agency move from Cleveland to the Miami Heat, where he formed a big three with Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh to ultimately win two title championships.

He even appears to be wearing a similar checked shirt in both shoots.

The Decision sparked criticism of LeBron James and turned public opinion against him. (Larry Busacca: Getty Images)

But part of what made that moment in NBA history so shocking was the surprise.

Almost no-one knew exactly what was happening until James sat down with Jim Gray on a court at the Boys and Girls Club in Greenwich, Connecticut and the special aired on ESPN.

It was perhaps the first major scandal of James's career after being drafted by the Cavaliers straight out of high school in 2003, with the NBA superstar criticised for drawing out the announcement that he would "take [his] talents to South Beach" until half an hour into the program.

LeBron and Bronny share NBA court Photo shows LeBron James and Bronny James walk onto the court together in an LA Lakers NBA game. LeBron James and Bronny James check into the Lakers' season opener together, becoming the first father-son duo to play together in an NBA game.

It stunned the Cavaliers and the rest of the NBA, which is why the tease this time has raised some eyebrows.

James is a savvy operator, with a production company of his own and any number of business interests and endorsements.

One of those, Uninterrupted, replied to the video on Instagram with: "All eyes on this moment."

The interviewer in the clip does not appear to be a well-known personality and it would be bold for James, who worked so hard to rehabilitate his reputation after the first Decision, to hearken back to it in announcing the end of his career 15 years later.

That prompted questions from many on social media about whether this was a fake-out that would turn out to actually be an advertisement.

James pulled a similar trick in June for what turned out to be an Amazon promotion, although that time he did hashtag "ad" in the post.

As was the case in the middle of the year, Jeff Bezos's retailing goliath has another promotional event set to start on the same day of James's announcement.

NBA content creator Molly Morrison summed up the vibe on X, writing: "we live in such strange times because either this is an ad or the sports world will be turned upside down."

But that hasn't stopped fans rushing to buy tickets for what could be the last game of an NBA legend.

Ticket seller TickPick reported that prices skyrocketed for seats at the Lakers' last regular-season game against the Utah Jazz, the same team against whom Kobe Bryant finished his career with a famous 60-point outing.

Seats had been selling for $85 but the cheapest available seat blew out to over $400 in the wake of his announcement.

A poll on their X profile had hundreds of respondents with almost two-thirds predicting it would turn out to be an ad.

Regardless of what happens, a retirement decision cannot be too far away for the 40-year-old.

He is a four-time NBA champion with three teams (Miami 2012-13, Cleveland 2016, LA 2020), being named Finals MVP in all those campaigns, as well as regular season MVP four times. He is also the highest point scorer in league history.

Last season he fulfilled what was perhaps his last stated goal, playing alongside Bronny after the Lakers drafted him late in the second round of the 2024 draft.

Bronny turned 21 the same day of LeBron's post.

title: Why has France gone through five prime ministers in two years?
text:
The sudden resignation of France's prime minister — the country's fifth in two years — has put President Emmanuel Macron in a bind.

Sébastien Lecornu resigned on Monday, just 14 hours after unveiling his new cabinet and less than a month after he was appointed PM.

It's become the latest saga in a period of almost ceaseless political uncertainty since Mr Macron dissolved the National Assembly in June 2024, triggering legislative elections that stacked the parliament's lower house with his opponents.

Here's a closer look at the unprecedented political drama that's been roiling France since then.

A 14-hour government collapses

When Mr Lecornu tendered his resignation on Monday morning, he pulled the rug from under the new cabinet that he'd named less than 14 hours earlier.

Agnès Pannier-Runacher, the newly reappointed Minister for Ecology and one of Mr Macron's loyal supporters, posted on X: "I despair of this circus."

Macron gives French PM two days to salvage administration after snap resignation Photo shows A man in a suit holds a press conference with a concerned expression. Mr Lecornu stepped down just 14 hours after naming his Cabinet, plunging France into another political crisis.

With ministers out of a job before they'd even had a chance to settle in, the collapse was a bad look for Mr Macron.

It reinforced the impression the French leader — who famously described himself as "the master of the clocks," firmly in control, on his way to winning the presidency for the first time in 2017 — is no longer in command of France's political agenda.

Perhaps more damaging for Mr Macron were the reasons Mr Lecornu gave for his resignation.

He explained that the job he was given less than a month ago, after the previous prime minister was tossed out by a National Assembly vote, had proven to be impossible.

Francois Bayrou was ousted as prime minister in September. (AP: Christophe Ena)

Mr Lecornu said three weeks of negotiations with parties from across the political spectrum, unions and business leaders had failed to build consensus behind France's top domestic priority: agreeing on next year's budget.

"Being prime minister is a difficult task, doubtless even a bit harder at the moment, but one cannot be prime minister when the conditions aren't fulfilled," Mr Lecornu said.

Why does France have a president and a prime minister?

France has a semi-presidential system of government, with power shared between the president and prime minister.

Every five years, the French people elect a president, who then appoints a prime minister — which also requires the parliament's approval.

Loading...

While the president's domain is foreign policy and defence, the prime minister handles domestic affairs.

Luc Rouban, a political science researcher at Sciences Po University in Paris, says it's unlikely Mr Macron will resign despite the internal instability.

"The central institution remains the president of the Republic ... he remains the leader on international affairs," he said.

No tradition of coalitions

When the snap 2024 legislative elections called by Mr Macron backfired and delivered a hung parliament, he believed his centrist camp could continue to govern effectively.

With no stable majority, they needed to build alliances in the National Assembly.

But the 577-seat chamber has broadly been split into three main blocs — left, center and far-right — and none with enough seats to form a government alone.

France has been in political turmoil since the June 2024 elections, which resulted in a divided lower house. (AP: Christophe Ena)

France, unlike Germany, the Netherlands and some other countries in Europe, doesn't have a tradition of political coalitions governing together.

Mr Macron's political opponents, particularly those on the far-left and far-right, have repeatedly teamed up against the president's prime ministers despite their own ideological differences.

The French leader's minority governments have toppled one after another, with Gabriel Attal, Michel Barnier, François Bayrou and now Mr Lecornu falling since September 2024.

Any successor Mr Macron chooses could be on similarly shaky ground.

Another dissolution possible

The alternative for Mr Macron would be dissolving parliament again, ceding to pressure from the far-right in particular for another unscheduled cycle of legislative elections.

Mr Macron has previously ruled out resigning himself, vowing to see out his second and last presidential term to its end in 2027.

But new elections for the National Assembly could be fraught with risk for the French leader.

Another election could result in more seats for far-right leader Marine Le Pen's party. (Reuters: Stephanie Lecocq)

The far-right National Rally party of Marine Le Pen, already the largest single party, could come out on top, an outcome that Mr Macron has long sought to avoid.

Mr Macron's unpopularity could also deliver a crushing defeat to his centrist camp, giving him even less sway in parliament than he has now.

Or France could get more of the same political deadlock and turmoil.

AP

title: Mystery Road: Origin screenwriter Erica Glynn has only ever written with mob
text:
It felt "pretty amazing" when Kaytetye woman Erica Glynn first walked into the writers' room for season two of ABC TV's Mystery Road: Origin.

It was the first time the series had an all-Blak writers' team, and it inspired an all-too-important level of trust for the screenwriter and director, known for Redfern Now and Black Comedy.

That trust was necessary considering the weight of the subject they were taking on: the Australian healthcare system, and the disparity between how it treats Indigenous and non-Indigenous people, as well as the part it played in colonial policies, like assimilation.

It was a "tricky" subject to tackle, Glynn admits.

"We're all dependent on a fairly luxurious national health system … but there are flaws, particularly in remote areas, and it's a fact of life," she says.

"Things go awry and things bugger up, and that's the truth."

Mary and Detective Jay Swan return for the second season of Mystery Road: Origin. (Supplied: Bunya Productions)

In season two of Mystery Road: Origin, junior Aboriginal detective Jay Swan (Mark Coles Smith), and his wife Mary (Tuuli Narkle) have moved from Jay's hometown of Jardine (the setting of season one) to the fictional town of Loch Iris.

It's around the time of the Sydney 2000 Olympics, and the couple are preparing for the birth of their first child. But their lives are disrupted when another child goes missing.

Past Jay stories — including the original 2013 movie, Mystery Road, starring Aaron Pedersen — have seen the steely detective take on the justice system through an Aboriginal lens. But in season two of Mystery Road: Origin, Jay finds himself up against medical institutions.

Glynn and her fellow writers — Steven McGregor, Jada Alberts, Gary Hamaguchi and Samuel Nuggin-Paynter — were all intimately familiar with how Australia's medical system can fail Indigenous people, whether from their own experiences or those of their loved ones.

On the set of drama miniseries True Colours, which Glynn co-wrote and directed. (Supplied: Bradley Patrick)

That informed the writing of season two of Mystery Road: Origin.

"Often, you're talking about very fragile, personal stuff [in a writers' room]," says Glynn.

" So, there was a level of trust around all of that sharing and getting to the guts of what is quite a prickly subject for our nation. "

Writing with mob

An award-winning screenwriter and director, Glynn cut her teeth working at the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) over three decades ago, and more recently co-created the crime drama series True Colours.

Having originally trained as a director, she initially came to screenwriting out of frustration.

"No-one was writing the scripts that I wanted to make as a director, so I had to start writing and found this whole new realm of creativity that I really, really love," she says.

Now, Glynn does more screenwriting than anything else. And, as a fan of the series, was "thrilled" when she found out there was a spot for her on Mystery Road: Origin.

Indigenous directors Wayne Blair (left) and Jub Clerc (right) on location with Mark Coles Smith. (Supplied: David Dare Parker)

But this wasn't the first time she's worked with an entirely Blak writing team. In fact, throughout her career, Glynn has exclusively written with mob.

"I've never been in a story room where it isn't all Blak," she says.

"That's either because I haven't done enough or because I'm lucky enough to be chosen to go into all these Blak story rooms."

Writing enigmatic characters

Coming to such an established character was a challenge for Glynn. After all, Jay has been at the centre of two movies and two TV series.

While the older Jay is guarded and weighed down with trauma, the detective of Origin believes justice is possible and can be a force for good.

Yet he's still enigmatic; his thoughts and feelings are rarely on the surface, even as he becomes more disillusioned with the systems in which he works.

That made him "difficult" to write.

Glynn feels "bloody good" about herself for having cracked such a character as Jay (pictured). (Supplied: David Dare Parker)

"You've got to give him emotional intelligence without a lot of dialogue," she explains.

There were writers in the room who knew Jay "very, very, very, very, very well", which was both a huge positive, and a barrier of sorts.

"Even talking about him in the story room was frustrating for me because Steven McGregor — who's written on all of the series and is the lead Blak writer — would go: 'No, Jay Swan wouldn't do that'," Glynn says.

But on the other side of that frustration came moments of breakthrough and "feeling bloody good about yourself" for having cracked the character.

Telling authentic stories

One of the best things about having an all-Blak writing team is the variety of perspectives and experiences on the stories and themes in the show, Glynn says.

This was particularly important when writing about Swayze (Aswan Reid; The New Boy), a young boy who is first introduced when the car he's driving swerves into Jay's path.

Feeling safe in an all-Blak writers' room meant Glynn could explore Swayze's (left) trauma. (Supplied: Bunya Productions)

Swayze "has fear in his heart" and at times it's unclear whether his fear is a manifestation of his trauma or grounded in something more immediate.

"Getting inside [Swayze's] mindset was fresh turf for me and difficult," Glynn says.

"Particularly with a subject like this, it was just absolutely crucial that it was all Blackfellas doing it.

"Also, I felt safe in all of that to be able to express what I needed to express or to be dumb and not know stuff."

She says they could even laugh about some of it.

"Not the tragedy of it all, but just to be able to be light when we needed to have light. It can be a pretty dark subject matter."

title: The AI bubble just got a little bigger and no one knows when it will burst
text:
The last tranche of those warrants can be exercised if AMD’s share price, which leapt more than 23 per cent on news of the deal to $US203.71, hits $US600. If all those warrants could have been exercised immediately, in agreeing to purchase AMD’s GPUs OpenAI would have created $US6.3 billion of value for itself from the $US63.4 billion the announcement added to AMD’s market capitalisation. Generative AI apps are tearing through workplaces and are now increasingly used for coding. Credit: iStock Altman has been engaged in a frenzy of high-stakes deal-making in recent weeks that adds up to mind-boggling sums. Apart from the Nvidia and AMD deals, he has committed to buying $US300 billion of computing power from Oracle and is partnering with Oracle, Microsoft, Softbank, Nvidia and others in the $US500 billion Stargate data centres project. He’s also negotiating with Broadcom to develop custom chips for its next generation of AI models.

OpenAI, via the deals with Nvidia, Oracle, the Stargate partners and AMD, has committed to acquiring the equivalent of about 23 gigawatts of computing power at a cost that it estimates will top $US1 trillion. The Nvidia and AMD deals alone will cost OpenAI about $US800 billion over time. The company that ignited the AI boom has been funding itself by raising equity and debt. It will have revenues of about $US13 billion this year, but will lose money because of the scale of the investments it is making. It expects to be profitable in 2029 – after burning more than $US100 billion of cash. OpenAI has more than 700 million users, but only about five per cent of them pay for its services. That’s reflective of the entire sector, where companies are committing tens of billions of dollars each this year in the hope that eventually there might be a massive commercial return. AI-related investments in the US this year are likely to approach $US400 billion and estimates of the investment required by the end of the decade range from about $US4 trillion to as much as $US7 trillion. The “hyperscalers” – companies like Google’s parent, Alphabet, or Meta Platforms, or Microsoft and Amazon – have the vast cash flows from their existing businesses to fund their investments in data centres and chips, but even they are showing signs of the strain of funding such large non-cash-generating investments.

It is improbable that all those chasing a position in whatever the AI sectors looks like in future will survive, given the financial stresses involved. The market’s enthusiasm for AI stocks is now being widely compared to the dot-com and telco bubbles a quarter of a century ago. When the dust settled, only a handful of the players survived, but Google and Amazon emerged with the foundations for today’s dominance established. Something similar could be expected if AI is as transformative as it promises to be, although the increasingly incestuous nature of the sector, the exposures to each other’s balance sheets, the need to continually access equity markets for capital consumed in recurrent spending – GPUs have a useful life of between one and three years before they are made redundant by the next generation of chips – and the increasing use of debt makes the whole structure of the sector vulnerable. Open AI and Nvidia are both allies and competitors in the quest for AI at, or superior to, human levels of intelligence. They are now formally linked via OpenAI’s commitment to buy Nvidia’s chips and Nvidia’s shareholding in AI. The deal with AMD, which is developing a chip it believes will rival Nvidia’s next generation of chips, diversifies OpenAI’s supply chain and helps a Nvidia competitor which, in turn, might generate some price competition (Nvidia’s Blackwell chips can cost up to $US70,000 each) and lower OpenAI’s own costs over time.

Good bubble, bad bubble It also, however, highlights the interdependencies that have developed in the sector, which is again reminiscent of what occurred during the dot-com boom and bust. Loading Amazon’s Jeff Bezos recently described the investment boom in AI and the stretched valuations afforded to anything AI-related within the sharemarket as a “good” kind of bubble, saying it was more of an industrial bubble than a financial bubble. He referred to the vast amounts of fibre optic cabling deployed in the 1990s that survived even after most of the companies that laid it didn’t as an example of a good bubble.

title: ‘You think you look fabulous – then you realise you’ve got knickers on your head’
text:
Born in Canberra, she trained in classical ballet (“in the womb,” she says, “lost in the martini mists of time”) before coming to cabaret. “I like the heightened form of it,” she says. “I think it’s much more true than what we pretend to be every day. I think being heightened is true. And wearing a uniform and pretending to be small is, you know, pretending. Being heightened is honest.”

“It’s for the unexpected,” she says. “And also I can have all these grandiose aspirations, but I’m very aware of my tiny place in the universe, and so it’s struggling with that.”

Meow Meow – or Melissa Madden Gray on her birth certificate – has been in the cabaret game a long time, starting with Perth Festival in 2001. She performs a style of “kamikaze cabaret”, which has been described as “always one step from disaster”. But behind the slips, wardrobe malfunctions and apparent missed cues is a sharp and savvy performer – every purported misstep is, in fact, a meticulously choreographed performance, designed to get the audience laughing and, as she says, slightly terrified.

This column is called Lunch With, but to be accurate, today it’s Brunch With, in deference to actor-dancer-musician-cabaret artist Meow Meow’s hectic rehearsal schedule. She initially requested that we meet at Brunswick Street institution Mario’s, but as I recently dined with fellow cabaret legend Moira Finucane there , we’ve ended up at Alimentari, two minutes down the road.

She’s performed everywhere (London, New York, Berlin, Sydney, Monte Carlo, Hollywood) and with everyone (David Bowie, the Berlin Philharmonic, Alan Cumming, Barry Humphries, Taylor Mac). She’s on the road so much that she doesn’t really have a home base – “the world is my home”. Of course that life is glamorous, but it also has a way of grounding a person.

She was performing a show at Carnegie Hall – “Carnegie Hall, listener!” she says, bending close to my recorder – when a friend convinced her to go back up to the foyer to see her sold-out show poster. “The elevators were broken, so we not only are carrying up all of my suitcases and many mannequins, as I made a fake band, I had a fake massive band on stage with me. The glamour!” She laughs. “Carrying mannequins and suitcases, and we wheel around, and the poster is down. The next one’s up.” It wasn’t the only elevator-related drama for the night, as it turned out; when she returned to her hotel she discovered her band was stuck in the lift. “We spent half the night with the fire department. It was hilarious. And then walking up the stairs in the hotel because I was too worried about the elevator, with a floppy mannequin banging on each step, thunk-thunk-thunk.”

Turkish eggs with labneh, merguez sausage, and pickled peppers and onions. Credit: Penny Stephens

She returns to this story several times through our brunch, as it’s emblematic of the kind of performer she is – a soaring, serious musician who has played the great concert halls of the world, but who also sees the gut-busting hilarity of dragging a mannequin, corpse-like, up the stairs. “But I think I like the shock of the ridiculousness of your pants being stuck in your knickers because it’s the real things that happen. You think you look fabulous, and then you realise you’ve got a pair of knickers on your head that you used as a scrunchie. Clean knickers, but still. Then you’ve got the audience in a state of slight apprehension, dare I say, and that’s a receptive audience, slightly terrified.”

There are no knickers on her head today, with Meow looking glamorous and smart in a black velvet tuxedo jacket, her signature wild curls framing her face and her green eyes sparkling beneath fake lashes that reach halfway down her cheeks. “I made an effort!” she laughs. She is slight and extremely beautiful, laughing often, but serious, too, when she talks about art – both hers and other people’s – philosophy, the state of the planet and truly dire state of the performing arts world post-COVID. She loves Alimentari and highly recommends the tuna sandwich for a future lunch. But as this is brunch, we both go for eggs – hers Persian (wilted spinach, shanklish cheese, dukkah, sourdough), mine Turkish (labneh, pickled red onion, aleppo pepper, merguez sausage).
